content: I'm going to say NO...it is NOT the mission of the military to keep you and your spouse together...some would find this detrimental to staying focused on the job at hand. Your marital relationship will always come after and behind the needs of the military, like it or not. I know a civilian doctor and his wife who work in the SAME hospital; they seldom EVER see each other. They are NOT even in the military. You must be realistic and realize that your job/duty to serve come first, and last. If you get lucky, count your blessings. Stay focused on your DUTY...don't let your priorities and commitments get all tangled up and skewed. The cost of letting that happen will be very high. - LHA-3 Rusty I wish both of you well.

content: Clear, Doc...I posed the basic precept of military service; as you well know, the military puts its personnel/forces where they can and will best serve the needs and missions of the military, not the personal and/or social relationships of those individuals. I hope the kid makes it...'taint a 'walk in the park', by any means! I want him to understand the reality of a commitment to military service life, regardless of what some suave-talking recruiter may tell him. I'm a two-tour fleet sailor from the 'old Navy'. My recruiter was straight-up with me...I am grateful he was honest with me. I never regretted my decision to join and serve, although there were times I questioned my SANITY in doing so; don't we ALL at some point in time?

content: Each of the services have an assignment program called "JOIN SPOUSE." Basically, under this program, the military will try as hard as they can to station military spouses at the same base or within 100 miles of each other. Note there is no guarantee -- the military just agrees to try. The services will not create a new slot for JOIN SPOUSE. There has to be an existing slot in the rank/job that the member(s) can be assigned against. Having said that ... you're talking about 2 separate services (even though a Marine is part of the Naval Command), this makes a Join spouse program that much harder! Good luck.

content: Military service is no cakewalk...and it shouldn't be...however, it is what you make of it. Two people from similar backgrounds can have opposite results from their military service experiences. It's largely what you make of it. Stay focused on what your goal is, and DO YOUR HOMEWORK, literally and figuratively. Remember, your OATH is to protect and DEFEND the CONSTITUTION, not the 'government' per se, or any one person, in or out of the Chain of Command. Do the right thing, for the right thing's sake. Obey lawful orders and maintain your military bearing. Be a GOOD representative of the United States and its military, ON and OFF DUTY. Be true to yourself and your fellow Americans. Do NOT fraternize with any detainees or others whose ultimate goal is detrimental to you individually or to your unit, your branch of service or your country. Recently, a U.S. guard stationed at Guantanamo fraternized with an Islamic extremist detainee nicknamed the "general". Now that former guard has been mentally compromised, undermined and has become an Islamic follower. This person let his guard down and is now paying the heavy price for failing to follow the rules. It CAN happen. Do NOT allow it to occur to you. Stay focused on your mission and goals. The 'ball' is in your court! Best wishes.
